  2301. The recommended replacement interval for these Jet Tips is 6 months, but I don't replace them if they are still working--the point at which the Jet Tip needs to be replaced is when water dribbles through it instead of in a strong, steady stream, or it won't stay seated in place in the Waterpik handle.<br /><br

  8. Water pick works but in order to stop water from coming out you need to hold button down. As soon as you turn unit on if you do not have blue button held down water starts shooting out. Purchased for my Daughter to help clean her expander. She ends up shooting water all over the place. Wish the button would dispense the water instead of stopping it. To brush is ok.
  9. I received this system hoping it would be great. I needed a new toothbrush since mine died and my dentist has been suggesting a waterpik. They advised me to start slowly if I did get a waterpik. The brush is great pausing every 30 seconds to let you know to change quadrants, but you have to pay attention because its a very brief pause. It's not as fancy as the latest and greatest out there, but considering you get both its an awesome price. I put mouthwash in the waterpick side because I struggle with soft enamel, sensitive teeth and dry mouth. I'm hoping by using my Biotene mouthwash in there I can improve my issues. The low setting is extremely gentle. My only complait is its not smaller so I can take it to work.
  10. excellant performance
  11. Great quality machine and we love how it works.
  12. I got one of these and it works so well my wife wanted her own. Now we have two!
  13. Electric than manual brush clean, coordination with the cleaning is very practical
  14. To keep it brief, this is a very simple setup. The toothbrush lasts about 2 weeks on a single charge for brief morning and evening brushings (each approximately 2 minutes). I always fill the reservoir with tepid water and spray until it is empty. For those who do not floss regularly, I recommend starting on a low setting (2, maybe 3) to gauge how your gums will react. I was flossing regularly with the tiny piks and I started on 4 which produced a bit of a bloody waterfall the first use. I dialed it back to 3 for the second and I have worked my way up to 6 now. I personally don't think I'll ever go beyond 6, which stings a little even if I don't bleed anymore.<br /><br />For anyone wondering, the toothbrush is waterproof, so you can use it in the shower without any worries of the battery getting wet and corroding. Also, the battery charges wirelessly when you insert it into its little cradle; very cool feature.
  15. The toothbrush totally stooped to work after few month of use

Great price on this unit.<br />Since I started using it my gums are 100% healthier, and I use the waterpik approximately 6 times a week, and I definitely regret when I don't use it.<br />It's a little awkward to get used to at first. At this point I can use it on 8 out of 10 without any problems, and don't feel its necessary to go any higher.<br />Can accommodate the use of water, or mouthwash/water combo and comes with numerous attachments.<br />The toothbrush comes with 2 heads, and runs on a timer to help get the full 2 minutes of brushing.

Recently we experienced water leaking from the reservoir bottom when filling it and then transferring it to the unit. We contacted Waterpik and described our problem. They provided us with a seal (and one extra) for the water reservoir (no charge) which I replaced and the reservoir no longer leaks. The product works fine and we would not hestitate buying one again.

  32. Works great! The only thing I don't like is when the toothbrush is on &#34;high&#34;, it vibrates in my head, so I keep it on low. Waterpik does the job with 4 different heads. I'd buy again. As of 5/4/15: I believe I figured out why there are a few reviews about toothbrushes that stopped working. I keep the unit plugged in all the time, and I went to use the toothbrush the other night and the bottom (where the battery is) was quite hot. I think that the unit is supposed to stay unplugged until the toothbrush needs charging again, plug in and charge, then unplug it as soon as it's charged. I don't remember seeing this in the instructions, but it's worth noting. I may not be correct in this assumption, but we'll see if mine keeps going or not by leaving it unplugged until it needs charging.
  33. Works well, wish it had 2 full power brush heads though. It is a little messy to use but what can you expect with squirting water...
  34. I order this from amazon for about 100$ and after just about a week of use im in love. The toothbrush is powerful but gentle at the same time. I can feel it scraping the junk off my teeth and can see a difference as well. To me the brush was a bonus I really came for the Water Flosser. I usually cant floss because my gums bleed and Im afraid of it. But after giving the water flosser a shot flossing will never be an issue and maybe i can return to normal floss after extensive use of this. FOR the price i payed it is well worth it and i would highly recommend to a friend. NOTE the brush is loud but if it doesnt bother you it serves its purpose very well.   37. So based on good reviews and a decent price for this set I went ahead and purchased it, so let me go ahead and give some impressions:<br /><br />1) instructions state should have a tongue cleaner, isn't one in the box. Not necessarily a big deal to me but found it odd that what is suppose to be here is not.<br /><br />2) The electric toothbrush isn't necessarily anything phenomenal, granted is does its job just fine. Any time it includes a built in timer is a nice feature but short of that I doesn't particularly find anything that differentiates it from a $20 electric brush. Maybe with time my feelings will change<br /><br />3) The water flosser was kind of disappointing, maybe I just expected to much? The unit vibrates... a lot... especially as you turn up the power, to which actually reaches a point where its pretty unnecessary. Playing with the power I actually got to a point where I could make my gums bleed, granted everyone's mouth is different and that's why the adjustment exists, but between the vibration and the noise from it I don't know if anyone is going to be using &#34;10&#34; on the power settings. The &#34;pause&#34; button is a physical stop as oppose to an electrical and due to this water will continue to pump through and squirt out just at a reduced speed. Aside from those things you can make a huge mess with this, which I know I will just have to learn how to use it properly over time to get the best results, but first few times you are guaranteed to get a few puddles on the floor.<br /><br />Because of the reasons listed, I give this product &#34;its ok&#34;, I'm not necessarily regretting my purchase but I can tell you I'm not excited about it at this point either.

  41. i loved this product and my boyfriend gave it a try. he liked it so much, he considered buying one, but instead i ordered him one as a gift. shipping got delayed for some reason, but no big deal - it's worth the wait and the price is very reasonable for a sonic toothbrush and the water-flosser.<br /><br />i hate flossing, and i rarely ever do it, but this method of flossing has increased my semi-annual flossing to bi-weekely. i'm sure my dentist will be pleased and so will my gums :)<br /><br />the sonic toothbrush is great but i don't know of any comparable sonic toothbrushes to say if it's better than the rest - while it's still better and quicker than manual brushes. it requires a 24 hour charge before use (pretty typical for any re-chargeable device these days) however the waterflosser can be used while the toothbrush is charging for the first day.

  67. I've owned a Waterpik water flosser since 2006. I purchased my first one from the oral surgeon who recommended I use it for general oral hygiene and specifically because I had large gum pockets around some of my molars. That first one was a [[ASIN:B006HG5A5G Model WP-100]], and it lasted six years. It worked quite well until it finally wore out, and I only had to purchase 2-3 replacement [[ASIN:B0062N5AZO Jet Tips]] for it in all that time. The recommended replacement interval for these Jet Tips is 6 months, but I don't replace them if they are still working--the point at which the Jet Tip needs to be replaced is when water dribbles through it instead of in a strong, steady stream, or it won't stay seated in place in the Waterpik handle.<br /><br />The second Waterpik I purchased in 2012 was a [[ASIN:B000063SLR Model WP-60W]]. I got it at a local Walgreens drugstore. This model was a problem from the start, because the reservoir was constantly leaking water. I know now, from reading today the excellent manual that comes with this Model WP-900, that my Model WP-60W had a defective reservoir valve and the warranty would have covered replacing it. The problem was, I did return it to Walgreens and exchanged it for another WP-60W, but that one leaked, too, and I didn't feel like going through the hassle of another return, so I kept the replacement Model WP-60W and have been unhappy with its leaking for the past 2.5 years. Since I had purchased my first two Waterpiks locally, and I had not gone online to research Waterpik when I did so, I wrongly assumed when I bought the Model WP-60W that somehow Waterpik had changed the design of their machine and messed up a good thing.<br /><br />Thanks to the wonders of Amazon, I discovered just this week, when I was looking to replace my Model WP-60W, because I just could not stand its leaking another day, that the reason my second Waterpik was so bad was that I had purchased a bottom-of-the-line model, of far lower quality than my first Waterpik, the Model WP-100, and I learned the different model numbers by looking at the pictures of the various models sold by Waterpik on Amazon.<br /><br />I was also due to replace my electric toothbrush, and I was fascinated by the information I read about the Waterpik Sonic toothbrush. Waterpik's ad copy on their website and on Amazon claims that the Sonic is much better than the Philips Sonicare, which is the brand I have used for over a decade in the [[ASIN:B009TZRQE0 Essence series]]. I had been fairly satisfied with the Sonicare, but mainly because it was the only brand I have ever used, so I hadn't compared it with anything else.<br /><br />I decided I would very much like to try the Sonic, but I noted that the price for the Sonic and a Waterpik higher quality water flosser model, when sold separately, would amount to about $170--a pretty steep cost and out of my budget.<br /><br />Then I ran across this model, the WP-900, at a terrific two-for-one price, offering a top-of-the-line Waterpik water flosser plus the Sonic electric toothbrush, and sold by a merchant here on Amazon for a price below retail. I snapped it up.<br /><br />It arrived today, and I am extremely impressed. Here are the things I like:<br /><br />1. The product is well packed, such that the flosser and toothbrush are well protected, but everything was easily opened--no clamshell horror packing.<br />2. The manual and quick-start guides are well written and well illustrated, and in print large enough that it is actually readable.<br />3. The product is simple to assemble, and the head of the Sonic toothbrush pops off (just pull it off, like taking a cork out of bottle, in an upward motion), compared to having to screw on and off the head of the Sonicare electric toothbrush. The brush head of the Sonicare also gets really sloppy and the inside of the handle has a well which gets very wet and has to be, with great difficulty, scrubbed out to remove mold buildup. There is no such problem with the handle of the Sonic. There is no well in the handle for water to get into.<br />4. The Sonic toothbrush's rechargeable battery arrived 1/3 charged, which was enough to immediately use it. It also re-charges much faster than the Sonicare. It has indicator lights to tell you how charged the battery is, whether 1/3, 2/3 or completely charged, which the Sonicare does not have and which I love.<br />5. The Sonic toothbrush has two speeds, which the Sonicare does not have. This is a terrific perk.<br />6. The brush of the Sonic toothbrush is smaller than the Sonicare, and the feel of the brush, including its size, shape and the vibration of its movement, is exponentially more pleasant and effective to use than the Sonicare.<br />7. This model of the Waterpik is like an expensive sports car beside a jalopy in comparison to the bottom-of-the-line Model WP-60W, and the WP-100 is like a mid-priced sedan in compared to the WP-900. I love the design of the separate, lidded compartments for the water reservoir and one that holds the water-flosser heads and the head of the Sonic toothbrush. The water reservoir comes off easily and fits in place easily, with zero leaking from its valve--what a relief!<br />8. The pause buttons on the Waterpik water flosser and the Sonic electric toothbrush both work much better than those on the Model WP-60W Waterpik and the Sonicare electric toothbrush.<br />9. The price of the replacement brush heads for the Sonic are about 1/4 the cost of the replacement heads for my Sonicare--which is a huge savings over the life of an electric toothbrush.<br />10. The insertion fittings of the Jet Tips of the WP-900 water flosser, compared to those of the Jet Tips for the cheaper WP-60W, are much higher quality, which means that the Jet Tips leak less and last longer.<br />11. This product has a two-year warranty for defects in its construction, and a problem like a defective reservoir valve can be solved at home, by getting a replacement part.<br /><br />All in all, I am in heaven with the great quality of this product. It works so much more effectively than what I've been struggling with previously, that I am able to do my dental care in literally half the time it took me with my Sonicare and Model WP-60W Waterpik.<br /><br />I could not be more satisfied with this product, and I recommend it without reservation.em with the handle of the Sonic. There is no well in the handle for water to get into.<br />4. The Sonic toothbrush's rechargeable battery arrived 1/3 charged, which was enough to immediately use it. It also re-charges much faster than the Sonicare. It has indicator lights to tell you how charged the battery is, whether 1/3, 2/3 or completely charged, which the Sonicare does not have and which I love.<br />5. The Sonic toothbrush has two speeds, which the Sonicare does not have. This is a terrific perk.<br />6. The brush of the Sonic toothbrush is smaller than the Sonicare, and the feel of the brush, including its size, shape and the vibration of its movement, is exponentially more pleasant and effective to use than the Sonicare.<br />7. This model of the Waterpik is like an expensive sports car beside a jalopy in comparison to the bottom-of-the-line Model WP-60W, and the WP-100 is like a mid-priced sedan in compared to the WP-900. I love the design of the separate, lidded compartments for the water reservoir and one that holds the water-flosser heads and the head of the Sonic toothbrush. The water reservoir comes off easily and fits in place easily, with zero leaking from its valve--what a relief!<br />8. The pause buttons on the Waterpik water flosser and the Sonic electric toothbrush both work much better than those on the Model WP-60W Waterpik and the Sonicare electric toothbrush.<br />9. The price of the replacement brush heads for the Sonic are about 1/4 the cost of the replacement heads for my Sonicare--which is a huge savings over the life of an electric toothbrush.<br />10. The insertion fittings of the Jet Tips of the WP-900 water flosser, compared to those of the Jet Tips for the cheaper WP-60W, are much higher quality, which means that the Jet Tips leak less and last longer.<br />11. This product has a two-year warranty for defects in its construction, and a problem like a defective reservoir valve can be solved at home, by getting a replacement part.<br/><br />All in all, I am in heaven with the great quality of this product. It works so much more effectively than what I've been struggling with previously, that I am able to do my dental care in literally half the time it took me with my Sonicare and Model WP-60W Waterpik.<br /><br />I could not be more satisfied with this product, and I recommend it without reservation.

  109. I did quite a bit of comparing between the Waterpik and the Sonicare brands. Here is how Waterpik tipped the scales. #1 When looking at the Amazon reviews I divided the bad reviews by the good ones. Even though there are negative reviews on both Waterpik had a far lower percentage of bad reviews. #2 Waterpik is made in the US. After using the product for a few weeks I am very, very pleased. (UPDATE) After using and loving this water pik for a little over a year, the battery in the toothbrush stopped taking a charge. It is not replaceable, although some handy people (who know how to solder) are able to replace it. The battery pak does come out for proper disposal, but Waterpik does not sell a replacement. And replacing the electric tooth brush alone is so expensive you may as well buy a new unit. I am replacing my Waterpik but I will be choosing another brand, because Screw You Waterpik, you suck!
  110. Love having both dental care products together. They both work well, and take up MUCH less counter space than my old pair.
  111. Great product, especially the dual speed brush!
  112. My dentist informed me that I was in the beginning stages of gum disease and that I needed to start using a sonic toothbrush and a water pik. I was so happy to find this on Amazon - both things I needed in one! I love the way the toothbrush has a timer to let you know when to move to the next &#34;quadrant&#34; in your mouth and shuts off after 2 minutes. The additional tips for the water pik are awesome too. I made the mistake of filling up the basin with cold water the first time I used it - OUCH! Cold water shooting between teeth hurts! Always fill up with warm water! :)
  113. Bought this barely two weeks ago, and the battery already died in the toothbrush. I havnt even set up the water flosser yet... If you're looking for a high quality electric toothbrush, this is definitely not what you want. It worked great for the two weeks it had power. I will be contacting Waterpik to get a new body for the brush, but it's a piece of crap with no way to recharge or replace batteries. Sort of a key feature of the electric toothbrushes - I obviously didn't look into it enough when I purchased my first electric toothbrush ever. Don't bother getting this model if all you're after is the water flosser, save the money on a simpler model

  134. I don't like doing negative reviews and tend to have a bit of mercy with companies if they've supplied good customer service when there's a problem. Such is not the case with Waterpik after my 5th phone call to them. I purchased a Water Pik Toothbrush/Water Flosser on June 6, 2014, from Drugstore.com, and was enjoying the use of it very much. In December, the button on the handle of the flosser began sticking. To keep the water from spraying all over the place until you get it where you want it in your mouth and then turn the dial to \\"on,\\" you can use the button to \\"pause\\" where there is no water that sprays out of the tip. A couple weeks later it was not working at all - just stayed stuck. Even when I pulled it out with a tweezers, it wouldn't allow any water to flow through. On Dec. 23 I called Water Pik since it was under warranty. They were very nice and said they would send out the assembly and explained how it was to be replaced. On Dec. 30 I received a box from them and in it was the water reservoir part of the unit. Obviously not what I was expecting, so I called on Dec. 31 to report the problem. They apologized and said they would send out the correct part and 2-day Express it. I waited until Jan. 6 (6 days later) and called again. Kelly said she would check on it and call me back with the tracking #. No call back. On Jan. 9 I called again and spoke to Kelly who informed me that the part had been on backorder and she didn't know why \\"they\\" hadn't told me that, but that it looked like it would ship today and I'd receive it in 3-5 business days. I asked about the 2-day Express and she said she didn't know anything about that since they weren't allowed to make those decisions. She said it would arrive in 3-5 business days so I'd have it \\"next week.\\" On Jan. 16, the end of \\"next week,\\" 7 days later, I called after the mail came and spoke to Lee who looked up tracking info to inform me that it was in Durham, NC (I'm in Central Virginia) and isscheduled to arrive on Jan. 20th. Hmmmm ... why don't I have a warm and cozy feeling about that? :-) I'm not feeling real good about customer service, warranty or reliability of Water Pik products.

  137. SO...I had extra money in my FSA, and I figured this was as good a time as any to get braces...boy was I not prepared for THAT life changer. What a time saver! I am pretty meticulous about flossing, so what would've taken me 30+ min with waxed floss and a floss threader was completed in about 3 minutes. I may make it through these two years of adult awkwardness after all.<br /><br />If you're in the market for a combination unit, I'd definitely recommend this one. It's nice and compact and has a limited 2 year warranty. Hopefully it lasts at least that long.   165. I read all the reviews on Amazon and took note of the problems people had, but the high ratings were encouraging.<br />After a month with the product, I am very happy with the purchase. The equipment is made of plastic and the internal components seem very basic...I know this because I took our 1st one apart, we don't live in the States and my wife fried our first one by plugging it into a 220v socket...it didn't like that, and neither did I because I missed that ultra clean feeling it had given me for the previous 2 weeks.<br />The 2nd unit we purchased is working as advertised, so far no problems with battery life on the toothbrushes. We do find that we don't use any of the extra extensions provided, just the toothbrush and waterflosser. The toothbrush refills can be expensive but seem very durable and you don't have to apply anywhere near the pressure you would use with a normal brush as it vibrates any stuff off the teeth easily leaving you with that fresh smooth feeling. That, combined with the waterflosser gives you such a complete clean that it becomes quite addictive to use.<br />Looking forward to hearing my dentists opinion on the next visit.

Waterpik has recently elected to make a change to our Water Flosser products to be more compliant with energy efficiency. The change included changing our motors to a high voltage direct current style, reducing the wattage consumption from 34 watts to 14 watts. The new motor is lighter and may be louder than the previous motor making it more efficient.<br /><br />So rather than this being a defect it appears it is part of the design.

  203. Arrived on time, excellent packaging. The WP-900 was crazy easy to use right out of the box. All I needed? An outlet and lukewarm water. I was bummed out the brush had to charge, because I wanted to try out the whole package. I did try the Waterpik... WOW WOW WOW WOW WOW!!!! Can you say amazing little product? I have sensitive gums, I mean really really really sensitive gums, like I bleed after every flossing, literally every flossing. I hate flossing because besides bleeding gums after the floss, I have swollen painful gums. So whether I floss a lot or a little, bleeding sore hurt gums and mouth. Enter the Waterpik. I put it in my mouth, rotated the head so it was comfortable, and turned it on, almost right away I turned up the pressure, and I get this sensation of water shooting between my teeth! Best part, after it was all over, almost no blood, and no visible bleeding! I was so dang excited I fired up the pick head and did front and back. And no bleeding. Not only no bleeding, but no swollen hurt gums, and my mouth feels super clean. I will have to do an update on the toothbrush later, but I think it is a shame, SHAME, i cN only give this little wonder 5 stars. Deserves way more. And you can't beat the price either! And I have Amazon Prime, so the 2 day free shipping was great. I was always hesitant and worried about killing my gums by using a Waterpik, no I'm never looking back! Don't wonder, just buy, I am excited to use the other heads as well. Clean, easy to set up, easy to use, all around terrific buy. Only real foreseeable issue?   208. Our Sonicare died after over seven years of faithful service. I put off replacing it as I did not like the redesigned head and the \\"enhanced\\" pricing for replacement heads. I had thought of Waterpik as strictly a water pick company, but by now, a lot of the old Sonicare patents have expired. The reviews on Amazon encouraged me to give the Waterpik a try. I am glad I did. I am happy to replace my manual flossing with it. The toothbrush works similarly to the Sonicare, minus the beep on the quadtimer. The pieces snap on with a satisfying click. The unit is well-built. Mine came with multiple brushes. I am not Type-A enough to use the different picks, being satisfied with the general purpose pick. If multiple family members are considering use, you might want to consider buying extra picks. My ONLY complaints about the unit, and they are minor, is that on the pick, you press the handle button to turn water off. If you should accidentally drop the pick or even loosen your grip, water can go everywhere if you are not careful. Also the waterpik device is a little fussy as to placement in its holder, and can fall out easily if you don't do it right. Otherwise, this would be a solid five stars.
  209. Convenient to have both toothbrush and pik in one spot to grab. Makes me look forward to my dental routine!

  214. Exellent poduct. Easy to use. Effective.
  215. My dentist recommended that I buy a Waterpik flosser for my family because it is the best way to get kids (mine are teenagers, 15 and 17, a boy and a girl) to floss.<br /><br />First, let me say that I bought the Flosser/Toothbrush combo because it was $69.99 and the non-combo was just $10 cheaper here on Amazon. (This retails for $99.99 on waterpik.com, so I figured I was getting a good deal.) I have not used the toothbrush because my kids will fight over it. Basically everyone wants it so no one gets it. That being said, I'm saving it for travel so I have no idea whether or not the toothbrush is all that good or not. Keep in mind, there is a cheaper 2-in-1 $49.99 version out there with only 3 jet pulse options. This is not the cheaper model. Mine has 10 jet pulse options, which is why I clearly put the exact item description in my title...so there should be no confusion about which model I am reviewing.<br /><br />This is the first water flosser my family has ever used. But we generally like it. The dentist was right, it's easy to use so the kids use it frequently. They've actually become so accustomed to the way it gets food out of their teeth, they use it after every meal now. That alone is worth the money, in my opinion. They've always been just &#34;okay&#34; at brushing their teeth, so they needed to floss more and this thing seems to keep them motivated to do both.<br /><br />I didn't give it 5-Stars because it does take up some counter-space and outlet space, which is a bit of a drag. Another thing I don't like is the mess. I would like to blame it on having messy kids, but even when I use it, there is always a puddle of water on the counter that needs to be wiped clean. I guess that's just what happens when you use a tool that squirts water. *Shrug*<br /><br />Like I said above, this unit has the ability to change the strength of the stream from soft to strong, with settings ranging from 1 to 10. We use it at a medium (6) setting because it shoots the food and plaque out from between the teeth and gums, without hurting. I found that when it's at full strength, the water jet can feel a bit sharp and cause bleeding. That's not a complaint, just a comment to give readers and idea of my experience with the pulse jet stream. Hopefully, for those wondering how strong it is, that helps you.<br /><br />This came with 2 water tips, 2 brush tips and a rubbery pointed tip. The water container is super easy to refill because it lifts out of the unit.<br /><br />We've only had our unit for a couple of weeks, so I can't speak to durability. If something goes wrong, I'll post an update.and plaque out from between the teeth and gums, without hurting. I found that when it's at full strength, the water jet can feel a bit sharp and cause bleeding. That's not a complaint, just a comment to give readers and idea of my experience with the pulse jet stream. Hopefully, for those wondering how strong it is, that helps you.<br /><br />This came with 2 water tips, 2 brush tips and a rubbery pointed tip. The water container is super easy to refill because it lifts out of the unit.<br /><br />We've only had our unit for a couple of weeks, so I can't speak to durability. If something goes wrong, I'll post an update.

  235. When the Orthodontist recommended this particular waterpik for our teenager, we had to buy it. The distal jet they had inserted in her mouth kept getting food stuck inside (as did the braces) leaving her with really obnoxious breath and a very sore mouth. We've owned the waterpik complete care water flosser and sonic toothbrush for a while now and have no complaints. If anything, we have extreme praise. I know it's pricey, but it's definitely worth it. Consider how much you spend each year on the dentist/orthodontist and decide if it's worth less visits and cleaner braces to go this route.

My sonicare brush was slow, this one vibrates FAST, and seems like it will do a better job. It comes with a travel case for the brush.

  244. Been using Waterpik for years and this is the best. Compact size, toothbrush with Waterpik takes little room on sink counter. Covered section for storing all tooth brush heads & picks is excellent sanitary design feature. Only thing missing is adapter plug to use when traveling
  245. I've always been the type of person who is regular with brushing and mouth-washing, but struggled to consistently floss. Attribute it to laziness, or whatever, but my teeth are very crowded and the space (or lack thereof) between my teeth made traditional flossing difficult. Anyway, my old electric toothbrush kicked it recently, and when I went on amazon to research a replacement, I found this amazingly reviewed and very competitively-priced sonic toothbrush/water-flossing combo. Honestly, I'd never heard of a water flosser before, but the thought of pressure washing my mouth intrigued me. So given that, the reviews, and the price, I figured I couldn't go wrong. After two weeks of using it, I would say the unit has exceeded my expectations in terms of mouth-cleanliness. I'm looking forward to my next dentist appointment to see if the expert inspection concludes what I feel: the combo of the sonic toothbrush and water flossing is much more thorough than anything I've done in the past. The only reason I didn't give the unit five stars is a couple of operational nit-picks, noted below. Some pros: Water flossing WORKS. I am continually amazed (also amused) at the amount of stuck food that ends up in the sink after being blasted out from between my teeth. The ability to finely adjust pressure, as well as the different tip options, are also very nice, and I find the water tank has plenty of capacity. The sonic toothbrush seems to be doing a great job as well, certainly better than my old mechanically-rotating electric toothbrush. I really like that it has the two-minute timer function, and ESPECIALLY that it pauses very briefly every 30 seconds to alert you to move to the next quadrant of your mouth. The storage section for the tips is very handy, and the travel case for the toothbrush is great. The whole package seems well thought out, with attention to the details. Some cons: The water pump for the flosser is pretty loud, especially when you turn the pressure up morethan halfway, which is every time for me. Definitely could wake up a light sleeper in an adjacent room, even with the door closed. As a couple other reviewers have mentioned, it would be nice if there were three speed settings for the toothbrush instead of two. The low setting is very tame, but the high setting is definitely aggressive, to the point where it could be a turn-off for some people. Where's the Goldilocks speed? The handle of the toothbrush gets very slippery when toothpaste inevitably works its way out of your mouth and trickles down the handle. The rubbery grips on it don't seem to function very well as... rubbery grips. Some contour to the body, rather than just a cylinder, would have helped here. All in all though, I'd definitely recommend it. Despite the few cons, it all functions well and I'm confident it's doing a great job keeping my teeth clean. UPDATE 12/5/2016 Well, after 20ish months, the battery stopped holding a charge after a brush and a half without charging. Popped open the bottom of the toothbrush to learn that... the battery pack is soldered directly into the board!!! Go on amazon to find out that a replacement toothbrush is.... exactly the same cost as a whole new WP-900! That's kind of crazy and very unfortunate. The battery pack doesn't even look especially proprietary or complicated.. just looks like a couple of AAA batteries bundled together and then hard-wired to the board. It's maintained my satisfaction with level of cleanliness, but now I'm stuck with the decision of &#34;do I REALLY want to spend another $65 to keep it alive?&#34; At the end of the day, the answer to that question is a begrudging yes... but not till I can't get through an entire brush on a charge.

  275. I bought this for my partner who is fighting gum issues in one section of her mouth. I made her open the box when it arrived and received only an &#34;Oh, OK...&#34; Ummm, not what I was expecting! She seemed hesitant to try the water flosser so I tested it out myself. As it turns out it's OK she wasn't thrilled because I have now fallen in love with brushing my teeth!<br /><br />It's been several weeks since the Waterpik arrived and we've been able to share the unit easily by swapping out attachments. As noted, the toothbrush arrives with two different sized heads, but they're both standard toothbrush shape and the smaller will work fine for an adult. So far I've only tested a single water flosser attachment so I can't comment on the different types, but the sensation is so refreshing and clean feeling.<br /><br />FYI, I was told to leave my mouth slightly open over the sink to let the used water pour out as the flosser shoots fresh water in. I assumed I was going to end up covered in my own drool, but the process is perfectly neat and tidy. Give it a try and you'll immediately have a sense of when you need to let water flow out of your mouth. No biggie.

I especially like the fact that it has two different speeds, and sometimes I use the lower speed, other times the higher speed. It works extremely well, and leaves my mouth feeling much better than it does after a regular use of dental floss. I think it is more effective at removing particles, while at the same time being more gentle on my gums. It is also easier, in general, and in particular it is easier on my hands than wrapping that floss around my fingers.<br /><br />This is such a pleasure, that I am using it without fail every night (I probably used regular floss about five days/week). The instructions say to \\"just let the water flow freely out of your mouth,\\" but when I try that, some water tends to stream down the handle and onto my hand and then down my arm and often down my leg. Maybe I'm not doing it right. In any case, it will get your teeth and gums clean and the brush is excellent, too. The travel case is nice and the battery will last a coupe of weeks. I have noticed now that beyond the routine morning/night use, I find myself constantly using this for a quick but thorough rinse after meals, snacks or coffee. There's no better way for getting pieces of a salad, or nuts or other little items that get easily wedged in your mouth. I have not noticed that issue at all, for what it's worth.<br /><br />Anyway, great product and I'm very glad I bought it.

Others had less power and were less effective in removing/ preventing plaque. On my last scheduled 6 month cleaning I was told that there was nothing for the hygienist to do and I should go to once a year. Also on other models I owned, the tubing eventually split and could not be repaired meaning I needed to buy a replacement. I now have 2 of these ( one for my wife so we don't have to share) and they are holding up very well.
  327. I am not sure how long Waterpik has been around but I have been using one since 1972.<br />I would probably still be using my first one but the hose severed into when it vibrated buy a steak knife I had on the kitchen counter. I usually keep it in the bathroom but it was during a remodel.<br />I have a second piece of property so I am buying this all in one electric toothbrush and Waterpik.<br />in no way does this replace flossing<br />but it is a quick and easy way to remove all those little pieces of spinach or not or whatever straight after meals.<br />start with a lower pressure and then work up go ahead and aim it at an angle right into the gum line because this gentle massage will keep the blood flowing and keep it healthy so you will never ever have gingivitis.

  348. After I accidentally left my expensive Phillips Sonicare toothbrush at a relative's house, the base was stolen in the mail (I know, some things are beyond belief, they actually left me with the head). I started looking for another one, but didn't want to fork out that sum of money again. I took a chance on this one after reading the reviews, and am glad I did. The toothbrush itself has two speeds, low and high. While some reviewers said the high was too high, I found it to be perfect- I like that much speed because I feel like I am getting a better cleaning. On the low speed, I would say the power equates to what your normal electric toothbrush would be. The water pick itself is awesome. I thought that it might be messy, but after getting the hang of it (which doesn't take long), it really isn't. Most of the time I use it on full speed. I have always had a lot of dental issues, but my last cleaning at the dentist went great, even though I was past due- and I am sure it was because of the water pick. The hygienist commented about how little plaque I had on my teeth. If you have gum problems, then you really need to get this. My gums used to be sensitive and bleed quite a bit, but voila- no more. Your gum health will drastically improve, and quickly. You can get to places you can't with a normal toothbrush and very effectively, and in 99% of cases, it can even replace flossing. It is very easy to use- all you have to do is fill up the canister with water and turn it on. The pick also has a pause button which is nice and keeps things from getting messy. I really don't think you will find a better toothbrush for the deal- especially considering all it comes with. There are multiple heads for the pick, though I typically just stick with one I like. The only negative I can think of is that it is noisy when in use. If you are trying not to wake up your partner, you might want to wait until later for the pick.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Get to those hard to reach spots with the water pick.<br />Drastically improves gum health.<br />Easy to use.<br />Great price.<br />Great power on the water pick and toothbrush.<br />Tons of heads for the water pick.<br />Rechargeable toothbrush.<br /><br />Cons:<br />A bit noisy.water pick.<br />Drastically improves gum health.<br />Easy to use.<br />Great price.<br />Great power on the water pick and toothbrush.<br />Tons of heads for the water pick.<br />Rechargeable toothbrush.<br /><br />Cons:<br />A bit noisy.

  355. Water water everywhere is right... But that's not all of it...<br /><br />It does come with 6+ heads for the water flosser. Easy to switch out. Holds 20oz of water, which isn't much when you 'prime' the unit, but refill after that and 20oz lasts a decent while. I'd say 3-4 flossings. The tooth brush charges in the stand attached to the base. All good things, but that's where it winds down.<br /><br />There are 10 pressure settings for the water pick. The button on the wand allows you to stop water flow while you are holding it down. With that in mind, unless you hold the button down BEFORE AND AS you turn it on...water everywhere. After figuring out the button I wanted to see the thing in action! I turned it down to the lowest setting (as directions state). Tested the pressure on my hand, nice a soft. Gentle pulsing... on high it even blasts away old toothpaste left on the sink from six inches away. So leaning into the mirror, I aimed the head every so precisely, released the button on the wand...and....WATER PARK IN THE BATHROOM! My mirror went from just being cleaned from chores an hour before my package arrived to looking like the kids just got done filling water balloons!<br /><br />I know, I know, close your d*mn mouth and use the thing blindly, right? Don't get to see it work, but heck; no more mess! That SUCKS in my opinion. Not my style. I am trying to figure a way to maybe use it in the shower if I can figure out how not to electrocute myself trying to improve my hygiene.<br /><br />Hope it helps:) Thanks for reading!

  359. went to dentist. wife was told she needed a sonic toothbrush. I was told I needed a water flosser. Both technician and dentist recommended waterpik. this unit meets both needs. it is pretty well constructed and sensibly designed. storage space for brushes and flosser, long cord but excess can be stored in the base. simple to operate. Only one thing to be careful of. If flosser head is not inserted fully into the handle before turning it on, water squirts all over and runs down your arm. Not a problem for a normal person setting it up for themselves. But, if you have a wife with a perverse sense of humour who under the guise of being helpful sets up your toothbrush, puts toothpaste on it, but then doesn't insert the flosser completely, watch out. I was a sceptic about this kind of thing, but my gums are healthier, my teeth whiter and my mouth feels really refreshed when done using it.

  363. My teeth are crowded/tight so flossing isn't easy and as a result I do it far less than I should. For the past few years I've been using the spinbrush that you can pick up for $10 nearly anywhere. It worked okay with a fresh set of batteries but as time went on they seemed to drain faster requiring frequent changes. Therefore, I decided to get a rechargeable system and at first was just looking at a sonic brush but then noticed this combo. Glad I did.<br /><br />Pro's:<br />1. It is about the same level of cleaning power at low as what I was doing but at high it's ridiculously powered. Can't imagine someone wanting something more powerful than this offers.<br />2. The water flosser is plenty powerful and I didn't know at first if what I was feeling was actually doing anything. So I aimed it at my dirty sink in need of cleaning and sure enough it removed stuff running water wouldn't from one foot away. No doubt up close it does better. Next after a week of using the unit I flossed my teeth to see how much it was removing. There was at most 1/10th of what I would normally find. Thus it works, great.<br /><br />Con's:<br />1. High power takes some getting used to, perhaps a medium setting for the next model.<br />2. It is messy but the solution just requires some thinking. Use the water flosser before a shower, etc. Don't be smart guy and put a suit on then complain you have stuff all over you. LOL<br /><br />Conclusion: It's a great set up that takes up just as much counter space as it looks like in the picture. For those that don't floss as often as they should this may be even better. It's a vast improvement over my previous efforts with less effort. Just fill with water and blast away. :) At this price very happy. Almost paid twice this cost for a sonicare toothbrush alone. Now I have one that provides just as powerful a clean and a waterpik. Score!

  376. If you're like me, you like pain. And if you like pain, then you need one of these! I also like that it pulses every 30 seconds so you know when to move the next quadrant of your mouth. I think it also uses inductive charging, as there are also no charging pins visible.<br /><br />The waterpik is great; it got stuff out from between my teeth even after I used regular floss picks. I can't wait for my next visit to see my dentist notices anything. Using it on the highest setting can be a little painful, but if that's your kinda thing, then crank it up to 10. However, on 4-5 is quite tolerable. Also, running it on the 10 setting is a little noisy, but is to be expected for a pump. On 4-5, it's not bad at all.<br /><br />Overall, it's definitely worth the money.

  400. Before i bought this, i went for a cleaning. Hygienist checked for gum pockets with millimeter tool and i ranged from three to six mm gaps (which is pretty bad indicating beginning gum disease). My gums were also bleeding pretty bad. I spent a couple hundred $ on a deep (and painful) cleaning and then bought this machine that week. I have been using it (both waterpik and sonic brush) once a day ever since with only a couple of gaps. Went to the dentist again yesterday. Gum Pockets had decreased down to mostly 1-3 with the six's down to mostly fours (a couple of fives). The same hygienist as before concluded that a normal cleaning was appropriate this time. So, in one (the next) visit to the dentist, i saved the money spent on this machine. Pretty good return on investment. (Hygienist did say that i should floss more... That this machine is not a full substitute.). Hope that helps. UPDATE: the machine (sonic brush) had a problem on high speed while still under warranty. I called Waterpik and without any problems they are completely taking care of me (and it) WAY beyond my expectations. Outstanding customer service from Waterpik. I would buy from them again without hesitation.

  412. I've used a ton of electronic toothbrushes in the past, and I can comfortably say that this is the finest I've used. The motion of the brush took a little getting used to (at first I felt like I was being electrocuted when I turned on the brush), as it's not a conventional motor that drives the brush...I'm no rocket scientist, but I believe it uses sonic waves to power the motion of the brush against the teeth. Well, however it does it, this brush does an exceptional job cleaning my teeth...both in front and the hard to reach teeth no one ever sees but the dentist in the back of the mouth.<br /><br />It charges very quickly...and a full brushing of my teeth leaves all three of the green lights still illuminated. The brush battery has lasted over a long weekend (4 full days) without a recharge, and that's with brushing twice a day.<br /><br />Changing toothbrush heads is very simple...as is the water pick tip.<br /><br />The water pick reservoir is large enough for my needs...I never run out of water in the tank while still needing to cover an area in the mouth.<br /><br />A helpful tip my dentist gave me: Fill the reservoir of half mouthwash and half luke warm water, and your teeth will reach a whole new level of clean and fresh. The anti-biotic nature of mouthwash helps to kill any bacteria inside your gumline, and the water pick obviously helps you reach the harder areas to get to when you floss.<br /><br />Definitely recommend this product to anyone looking for a state of the art powered toothbrush and water pick.
  413. performs as expected; quick delivery
  414. Fantastic, I have sensitive problem gums and the sonic brush with its soft bristles is just what I needed. This works so much better than any of the other power tooth brushes I have used in the past it is like night and day. I enjoy using it. It has a minute timer, it does not spray tooth paste in every direction when it leaves your mouth while in operation. It is well designed and does not leave an accumulation of paste build up on the handle or base. The water floss works very well. I had an entry level version that was only marginal. This far exceeds that old one. Everything fits well in its holder and stays in place. Very Happy with this.
  415. When I began to have some dental issues, I was frustrated because I brushed and flossed my teeth daily. However, I knew I needed to do something quickly to help my gums and teeth to be stronger.<br /><br />WHAT IS THE WATERPIK COMPLETE CARE SYSTEM LIKE?<br />(In doing my research, I found that I had a hard time figuring out how this system would work. It is for people in similar mindsets that I am writing this review)<br /><br />WHAT TO DO FIRST<br />The first thing that you do is set up the area that you plan to put the unit. The footprint is similar to a women's size 5 shoe. It needs to be near an outlet which should be near the sink that you plan to use this system in. The unit has to be set up so that the water bin is closer to you. The tops of the unti all go in the opposite side of the unit where there are holes for them to stand up in.<br /><br />The toothbrush base has to be charged up. Mine took overnight to reach full status with three lights on it. The lights will stay lit to let you know what the charge is after you use it for a few seconds.<br /><br />HOW TO USE THIS UNIT<br />My family has a toothbrush head for each of us. I prefer the smaller head which comes in the unit. My daughter and husband each have a larger head that they use. They all have different colored rings on them so they can be told apart. You can also each have different reguiar tips for each of you if you prefer- this kit comes with two.<br /><br />TOOTHBRUSH<br />When you first use the flosser, I find that it is best to brush our teeth first. You can set the toothbrush on gentle speed (sensitive teeth might like this one) or high speed. At first the high speed feels very intense, but in the long run, if you work up to it, it really does clean the teeth well.<br /><br />Make sure that the toothbrush is in your mouth before turning it on. That will spare you splatters everywhere. Every 30 seconds the brush will pause briefly to let you know it is time to move to the next quadrant. I don't listen- I am a random brusher and go all over for 2 minutes. Once the brush is done, we remove the top and stand it up in the unit or other storage space.<br /><br />THE FLOSSER<br />Using the flosser is not hard to do, it just takes some practice to learn your own method. First of all, the first time, the blue basin comes out of the unit. You rinse it and fill it with warm water. Then carefully replace the basin in the unit lining up the plug with the black seal on the unit. Once it is firmly placed in there, you put in the tip that you want and with the tip IN YOUR MOUTH BEFORE STARTING, you start the unit.<br /><br />I recommend you start on gentle- the lowest of 10 settings- so that you can take some time to develop the method of use that works best for you. Once you have figured it out, then higher speeds are not as difficult to work with. We each have our own method of use. I tend to lean my head over the sink tilted slightly to the side. My husband turns his head completely to the side, letting the stream of water run out of the corner of his mouth. My daughter prefers to use it in private so I don't know what method she has worked out yet. She has used this with braces and now retainer and loves it.<br /><br />There is a button on the flosser which pauses the stream so you can take it out of your mouth, rearrange it or turn it off without water spewing everywhere.<br /><br />HOW WELL DOES THIS UNIT PERFORM?<br />My family rarely agrees completely on anything. We all have our own preferences and usually there are things we disagree on even if we agree. This system, however, has made us all rave as we all have seen a big change in our tooth and gum health. I am due for a cleaning after a long period of not being able to afford any, and since getting this system, I have found that my teeth have been looking cleaner and cleaner as I continue to use this.<br /><br />Gum bleeding has been reduced to almost nothing for all of us.Our daughter's mouth hardware has been fabulously cleaned and she really loves the different heads. She uses the orthodontic tip for her teeth. My husband and I use the classic jet tip for now, and eventually I will use the pik pocket top once my teeth have been deep cleaned and settle down. I have also used the plaque seeker tip and found it to be very useful around the gum area.<br /><br />To test this, I have used the waterpik flosser on medium after brushing my teeth on high speed. Then I floss with floss to test and see if anything was left. I have found one or two tiny pieces wedged in high up on the tooth, but that is it. My teeth usually hold a lot of debris, so this is quite impressive!<br /><br />ANY DISLIKES?<br />The only things that I can say that we have not been crazy about has been trying to find the right manner to get the stream running out of the mouth with the least amount of mess. It is possible, but the way that the teeth are cleaned is so good, I am willing to put up with it. You will get wet using this- but it is not overwhelming. For people who really hate messiness in any form, this might not work out well for you.<br /><br />THE BOTTOM LINE<br />This system comes with 2 classic tips, 1 plaque seeker tip, and pik pocket tip, a large toothbrush head and a compact toothbrush head. Between the things that this comes with, my family (with the addition of another brush head) has found this to be really revolutionary for our tooth and gum care. After use of both the brush and flosser, I have flossed with tooth floss and found almost nothing left every time.<br /><br />We have not had any problems with the toothbrush not holding a charge, but we have had this under a month. I will update if we have any problems.<br /><br />Although messy at times, our teeth have never been cleaner. I am very happy with this system so far. I will update with any new insight or information.Our daughter's mouth hardware has been fabulously cleaned and she really loves the different heads. She uses the orthodontic tip for her teeth. My husband and I use the classic jet tip for now, and eventually I will use the pik pocket top once my teeth have been deep cleaned and settle down. I have also used the plaque seeker tip and found it to be very useful around the gum area.<br /><br />To test this, I have used the waterpik flosser on medium after brushing my teeth on high speed. Then I floss with floss to test and see if anything was left. I have found one or two tiny pieces wedged in high up on the tooth, but that is it. My teeth usually hold a lot of debris, so this is quite impressive!<br /><br />ANY DISLIKES?<br />The only things that I can say that we have not been crazy about has been trying to find the right manner to get the stream running out of the mouth with the least amount of mess. It is possible, but the way that the teeth are cleaned is so good, I am willing to put up with it. You will get wet using this- but it is not overwhelming. For people who really hate messiness in any form, this might not work out well for you.<br /><br />THE BOTTOM LINE<br />This system comes with 2 classic tips, 1 plaque seeker tip, and pik pocket tip, a large toothbrush head and a compact toothbrush head.   432. Flosser + sonic brush at a great price! I've been waiting to buy a sonic toothbrush and I am not disappointed. I was planning on buying a Philips Sonicare but I decided on getting this Waterpik combo. Everything works as advertised, but I'm disappointed that this combo isn't Made in the USA. When I received the box, it plainly states Made in China, Designed in the USA. As a notice to future Waterpik flossers, I don't know if this pertains to just me, but my dentist recommended that I don't exceed past 4 on the pressure setting. More than 4 would actually result in damaging my gums. I haven't found any YouTube videos of it yet, but you can actually change the battery in the brush. You just need to buy the battery from eBay or another online supplier, and solder the battery onto the board. Check YouTube before throwing out your dead toothbrush! My brand new toothbrush lasts under 2 weeks, brushing twice, on the highest setting.
  433. Quick delivery and good quality
  434. OMG I LOVE my new Waterpik (R) ultra flosser complete with toothbrush. The toothbrush tells you when you need to change quadrants (stops vibrating temporarily) and the waterpik has a rubber tool to get into the deep pockets as well as a ton of other attachments for everyday use. I use one cap of Advanced Care Listerine & the rest water in the reservoir (Which detaches for easy cleaning)and I have to say it is the best!! Wish I started using this years ago. Sonic toothbrushes have come a long way since I last owned a Sonicare! Cheap on Amazon too. Trust me $100 is nothing compared to what the dentist charges!<br /><br />It just went on sale down from $89.99 to $72.52 and just called and they gave me the difference. Telling you this thing is the best mouth care item I ever purchased. I went over the gum line with a rubber pik after my brush & waterpik and there was nothing that came off. FABULOUS!!! I am so OCD about my teeth and will be even more so now but with less trouble! I am now done with my routine in less than 5 minutes and no more manual flossing. I highly recommend the product and am now a reformed Sonicare user! It even got particles out of the back molars that flossing used to take multiple passes to get out. My dentist even noticed the difference after 2 weeks of using it when I got my crown put in post root canal. A helpful hint is not to follow the directions my keeping your mouth open and letting the fluid drain. I recommend flossing each quad with your lips pursed, press the pause button on the handle, spit and resume. that way you will have little to no splash. As an RN, I find it really easy to clean too. PS- Brushing before the pik seems to be more effective for me as well as filling it after each use so it is ready to go next time.

  518. Small learning curve to avoid mess, but still gets great results.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Doesn't irritate the sensitive part of my gums - neither the brush nor the waterpik.<br />-Small brush head and a large brush head. Easy to remove. Nice travel case.<br />-Timer made a bigger difference to me than expected. Keeps me focused on getting a good brushing in.<br />-I can feel the bristles getting in between my teeth where my last electric brush did not.<br />-High-speed setting means business.<br />-Completely enclosed/waterproof brush - Charges brush with no cables; it charges just being next to the unit (in the holder).<br />-Rubber feet keep unit in-place and will fit on very small surfaces.<br />-If a big bottle of Listerine fits, this will fit. My sink is tiny and this fits on the corner where soap/lotion normally is.<br />-Also fits under the mirror/medicine cabinet. I can open it fully without moving it.<br />-Water pik itself isn't too messy. I don't let water &#34;just drain&#34; from my mouth. I pause it, spit, and resume. Works fine. Less mess than &#34;just letting it drain.&#34;<br />-Put a little mouthwash in it while you rinse. Gets Listerine under the gums.<br />-Pik head compartment/holder is removable. This means wife and I can share one unit when we travel, but bring our own sets of pik heads.<br />-Price is awesome. I probably would have paid this price for just the toothbrush. I almost did, in fact. Instead, bought two of these. Glad I did.<br />-Small enough to travel with whole unit.<br />-It's essentially a mini pressure washer. I pressure washed a few fragile hobby items with it - worked great.<br /><br />Cons:<br />-I'd prefer a mid-speed setting instead of just low and high, but I'm over it.<br />-Only works with 110v (USA). When I travel in Europe, I have to bring a kick-down transformer to use it. I'd prefer it had a power brick like a laptop, so I could just change it with a 220v version, but this is a very small complaint and won't apply to most people.<br />-Some of the extra piks seem a little pointless in my opinion, but they work fine.<br />-It doesn't make breakfast or shave my face too.

Getting used to the Waterpik part took about 4-5 times to get the hang of how to hold it without getting water splashed out of my mouth, but the feeling after is wonderful. When I pressed it, it wouldn't spring back up and I had to manually pry it out before I could continue to use it. I called Waterpik, but they said that there's nothing they could (or would) do because I had bought it off Amazon and because I wasn't in the US, I was not eligible for an exchange or repair, and that's fine. However I didn't like the tone the lady on the line (or the customer service in general) – she wasn't even interested in helping me, and was unapologetic – even my 2 initial emails to their customer service went unanswered.<br /><br />So I brought my grievances to Amazon, and they immediately sent me a replacement unit – plus apologized for the inconvenience.<br /><br />So although I give Waterpik 4 stars (didn't like that my unit was faulty), it's zero stars for Waterpik's customer service, and 5 stars for Amazon's quick resolve of my issue.

I did not know that a brush can be that effective in cleansing my teeth. My reference is my Oral B rotating brush experience.   711. I've had the Waterpik WP-900 for about a month now and I am glad that I purchased it. I primarily purchased it for the Waterpik flosser since I didn't really have much faith in the sonic toothbrush (my last sonic toothbrush was a Sonicare), but was I wrong!<br /><br />Sonic toothbrush<br />Pros: The toothbrush itself has two settings: one sensitive teeth and non-sensitive teeth. Once the on button is pressed, you get the sensitive setting first and then the normal setting (something I wasn't aware of until I tried turning off the toothbrush). It is very effective in giving you a thorough cleaning and knocks out any annoying pieces of food still lodged between teeth with ease. Waterpik's sonic toothbrush also comes with two brush heads: a normal one and one for sensitive teeth.<br />Cons: The toothbrush can be a bit loud when used.<br /><br />Tips: Be careful where you point the thing! I've had to wipe away toothpaste from my mirrors frequently.<br /><br />Flosser<br />Pros: I haven't had the super clean, just-got-out-of-a-professional-dental-cleaning feeling outside of my visits to my dentist until I purchased the flosser. The flosser comes with several attachments that range from general cleaning to specialized attachments made for those with braces. However, the one that I always use is the general cleaning one and it gets the job done nicely. There is a knob that allows the user to control the pressure of the water which allows those who would prefer a gentler clean the option to have one.<br />Cons: The flosser can get really loud which makes it really annoying to significant others/roommates. The sound that the flosser emits is very similar to one of a more quiet jackhammer once its on. Also, be sure to make use of the button which stops the water from flowing out; You can easily turn a dry bathroom into a water park if you don't use it. (Okay, maybe not a water park but definitely an aquatic mess)<br /><br />Tips: The reservoir is taken out by lifting the lidand then pulling it out (took me a while so I hope this saves you the wondering). Also, putting a bit of listerine in the water of the reservoir gives you some extra added freshness (;<br /><br />All in all, I'm very happy with my purchase!

  739. I purchased this item May 27, 2014. On July 3, 2014 a few days after the Amazon return window closed, the Sonic toothbrush stopped working. Not sure where to go from here. Hopefully, Sonic has a warranty period for the toothbrush. I'll report back.<br /><br />Update. Contacted Waterpik support. I was told that the reason this device would not work in my bathroom was that it needed to be attached to a outlet that either had a surge protector on it OR contrary to expectation was more than the standard 15 amp outlet. However, the device worked OK in the living room! The reason for this was that this device has \\"fluctuating\\" current and can trip a GSI. I have a GSI in the bathroom and reset it when the Waterpik did not work. The same support guy told me that I had 90 days to return things to Amazon. I was also informed of the option of returning it to Waterpik and \\"starting the return process.\\" Haven't decided what to do yet or what to believe.<br /><br />More later.

  766. I've had this for 4 days and I'm trying to figure out how I lived without it.<br /><br />Waterpik: The waterpik flosser is fantastic. I read some reviews about people having a hard time with getting the hang of using it without getting water everywhere but I have had a very easy time with it thus far, aside from the first time I turned it on and realized it should already be in your mouth when you hit on. ;) Although I do like to turn it on 1 facing down into the sink for a few seconds prior to use so that it clears all of the water that may have been sitting in the tubes from the previous use. I would suggest starting with the setting in 1 and working your way up to what pressure is comfortable for you, I have found that 4 is a nice pressure for me.<br /><br />Toothbrush: Wow, this toothbrush is fantastic and conveniently times 30 second intervals and shuts off after 2 minutes to ensure you pay proper attention to each area of your mouth and don't fall short of your 2 minute brush.<br /><br />I honestly feel like I've just left the dentist after each use. My teeth feel so nice I find myself constantly running my tongue over them. After just 4 days of using this product I can already see improvements in my teeth and gums. I have also noticed that my breath is staying fresher longer. I used to find myself feeling very self conscious about my breath by the end of the work day because I could feel a funny taste in my mouth and knew I needed to brush, now my breath stays fresh so much longer! I would absolutely recommend this product to anyone, I feel it was a great purchase. This is also a great deal, the waterpik WITHOUT the toothbrush is in my local grocery store for $59.99 and the toothbrush on its own will run $89.99 so don't pass this deal up!

  776. PROS: Is nice to have waterpik and toothbrush in one unit. Was worried about counter space but did not take up much. The sonic motion of the toothbrush sometimes helps break free congestion in my sinus as I brush and the adjustable rate of the waterpik was nice after periodontal surgery. The battery holds a charge rather long.<br /><br />CONS: The waterpik leaks out the whole water bin if the handle pops out of its cradle. The cradle for the handle is just a cheap tapered piece of plastic to cup around the body of the waterpik. The button now sticks on the waterpik, so if I need to stop water flow I have to use the power switch. If you have the adaptors lid open and go to open the reservoir lid, the stand pops out the adaptor container. Water level markings are inside the reservoir, not out side where you see 90% of the time. The cord to the waterpik does not wrap up nicely back into the base, most times.

  778. While the product package mentions the following clearly<br />What's in the Box<br /><br /> Complete Care Combination Water Flosser + Sonic Toothbrush<br /> 1 Classic Jet Tip - For general cleaning<br /> 1 Plaque Seeker Tip - For implants, crowns, and bridges<br /> 1 Orthodontic Tip - For braces and orthodontics<br /> 1 Pik Pocket Tip - For gentle, low-pressure delivery of antimicrobial rinses<br /> 1 Standard Sonic Toothbrush Head - Gently target hard-to-reach areas<br /> 1 Compact Sonic Toothbrush Head - Excellent access for precision cleaning<br /> 1 Premium Sonic Toothbrush Travel Case<br /><br />I received the pack with no floss tips as well as no brush head. As one can imagine the product is useless without these. After contacting customer service I've been given only one option get a 20% refund. However when you buy the tips and head separately there is quite some gap in the price (in additon to exchange rate, excise duty etc. since I am an non-US customer). In effect I am paying shipping and excise duty twice for the same parts which is completely unjustified. Why will the customer bear the price of this kind of a mistake in shipping?

  848. I asked my hubby for electric toothbrush for Christmas and he got me this. I was a bit disappointed initially and wondered what I'm going to do with such a bulky toothbrushing set. All these feelings were gone after the first time I used it. The electric toothbrush is good, nothing our of the ordinary, just does its job. It buzes at certain time intervals to tell you it has been 2 minutes. The flosser part is wonderful. I never thought I would say this, but I'm actually enjoying flossing my teeth. You would be amazed how much stuff stays between your teeth after brushing (and you see it all in the sink when you spit out the water). You can adjust the pressure to a level comfortable to you and with a variety of heads it comes with, you will find something for you. No more dealing with dent floss or floss picks.<br />The only con I have about this is that it is a bit loud, a bit more than most electric toothbrushes (the flosser part is loud) so your sleeping mate might not appreciate the wake-up in the morning.

I do like the fact that the whole setup is in one place which makes it very convenient to use. I don't have much room on my sink either, but I don't think that it takes up that much room.   898. I wish I had bought this years ago. I believe it does a very good job of flossing. However, I would not buy the model with the toothbrush. As you may know, there have been marketing wars between the Braun rotary brush and the Sonic Care up and down action brush,such as the water pick has. I know for a fact that Braun is better. I had switched to the brush that came with the water pic when I received it. Occasionally, I fail to brush my teeth often enough, for example, if I am traveling. The back of my upper front teeth felt &#34;fuzzy&#34; as if they needed to be brushed. I used the water pic brush and it didn't quite make my teeth feel smooth again. I then switched to Braun and it worked much better.<br /><br /> I have decided to add the following to all my reviews:<br />Beware! Some &#34;reviewers&#34; will trash a product for no reason simply because they are paid to do so or because they sell competitive products. Other &#34;reviewers&#34; will give products - that they have never seen and never used - glowing 5 star ratings - for a fee. Some honest reviewers do not understand what a product is for or how to use it and will trash a product simply because they are just plain dumb. And the biggest of companies have been heavily fined for hiring an army of “reviewers” to review their products.
  899. This flosser works great, but I must say that this is very rickety and cheap. As well, I did not receive the tongue attachment. It also leaks a big puddle underneath the machine every time I use it. But having said that I do think that this product will increase your dental health, if it holds up and doesn't leak too much, that is.
  900. Works well but messy I don't use it before heading out the door unless I put a towel around me. I have teeth very close together and flossing with string was not working and taking me a long time without great results. Mouth feels a lot cleaner.
  901. I love that there is a pause button on the water flosser!
  902. overall a pretty good product. The waterpik takes a while gettting use to. The toothbrush is easy to use and effective. I would recommend this product.
  903. I am giving this product one star for a few reasons:<br />(I used this product for two days trying to give it a chance, but it is not good for me)<br />first, the toothbrush head is very soft and i does not vibrate much. The only thing that vibrates is the handle. the toothbrush has two speeds, on speed one i feel the vibrations of the handle, but still have to perform round movements to brush my teeth (i guess because the head does NOT rotate). On speed two, the vibrations of the handle are so strong that once i even got a nerve twitch in my cheek where the toothbrush touched (god knows what it was but it scared the heck out of me). that has never happened to me before in my 4 year history of using electronic toothbrushes (previous was braun and lasted me for 3,5 years). On speed two the vibrations are very VERY strong. It doesnt feel pleasant to apply the toothbrush head on my teeth.<br />Second, the waterflosser does not impress me. I have never had waterflossers before, and it is possible that i had higher expectations. i have a bridge that needs to be cleaned daily. So, i expected 2 (am + pm) uses a day will keep it somewhat clean. Nope, thats not the case.<br />overall, my mouth does not feel clean after using this set.<br /> i think ill have to go with a rotating head toothbrush and a simple floss.
  904. Box was open and obviously repacked. An item I am going to use in my mouth, now come on! Sent back and didn't reorder. I have received several repacked/ reused items. This is routinely done at Amazon. It is careless and obvious. I want a new unopened item not someone else's reject.
  905. Never had a water flosser before and I needed a new electronic toothbrush so this ended up being a good buy for me. Flosser takes a little time to get used to it, but I managed to find a technique that works for me after squirting water all over the first few times. Lol.
  906. After many years of manual brushing, I took the chance on one of those rotary pulsating brushes, Oral B to B exact. That was my first venture in powered tooth brushing and not my last. That brush lasted about three years; twelve brush heads and around $120 later, I went into the ultra-sonic field of brushing. Sonicare was the best brush experience I had to date in my middle aged life. That brush too lasted around 3 and even possibly 4 years. Although the replacement brush heads were much more costly than the Oral B ones, and ultamitly the replacement cost of the brush heads is what drove me back to purchase another Oral B rotary type tooth brush.<br />Let me say neither of my first two electronic tooth brushes ever quit, or even slow down. It simply got to the point of replacement heads cost total, matched the total cost of the tooth brush when purchased.<br />Well I went back to the Oral B simply because I could not bring myself to justify the Sonicare price + the brush head price.<br />This time, my Oral B stuck around for 6 months. I simply never felt the same &#34;clean&#34; feeling on my teeth as I did with the Sonicare.<br />WELCOME WATERPIK<br />Now here is the Waterpik flosser and sonic tooth brush.<br />In short, I have owned this for 3 months and I will never go back to either Oral B or Sonicare. The cost for this unit complete is on par with a mid line Sonicare and the Oral B. However, you also get the water flosser and five floss heads.<br />Top that with the sonic toothbrush, and 2 brush heads, and you have the perfect combo for a healthy mouth.<br />The only thing I can report that may push some away from purchasing this is the sonic brush has two speeds.<br />I feel the low is too slow and the high is a bit too fast. However I also feel it does a fantastic job and in my opinion, beats out Sonicare in the tooth cleaning department.<br />If you have never used a sonic toothbrush, this combo is your chance. Use the low and you are good to go. Then when you are ready, brush on high and you will feel your teeth gleaming.Then when you are ready, brush on high and you will feel your teeth gleaming.

I was skeptical at first because I never actually used a water flosser before and thought that this wouldn't be good for me to use but I was taken aback by how good this is. I never had purely white teeth all of my life and after a few months of this, everyone keeps telling me that I have the whitest smile they have every seen for someone who wears braces.
