  912. Waterpik Complete Care Water Flosser and Sonic Toothbrush (WP-900)<br />I am in awe. Lets go per degrees. I read all negative reviews before i bought this water flosser. I decided that since the producer offers such great warranty it was worth the risk to get a defective piece. I have been using this machine for 4 days now and so far so good. Every component works fine. I got 2 general use picks and no tongue piece but i dont really care, i rather use the old school toothbrush on the tongue anyways.<br />I have a severe bone loss and gum disease. So bad every brush was a blood bath, flossing a terrible painful chore, i couldnt eat an apple without bleeding. Hence why i bought this machine on the verge of desperation. I debated if buying the pick only or the brush combo. I dont like electric toothbrushes. My husband does so I bought the combo. I noticed how the combo has a separate tank and a separate compartment where to store the picks, while the waterpick only has a compartment on the lid of the tank for those.. not funny i opted for the combo JUST for that reason.<br />Reading reviews from others i can clarify few little things:<br />- i was expecting some huge monster but it is quite compact and will fit in any standard shelf (NOT the med cabinet tho)<br />- i found easier to use a cup to fill the reservoir.<br />- i plug the machine when i use it and unplug it when i dont so that the toothbrush wont get an overcharge. People complained their toothbrush died after a month or 2 but come on use common sense. Anything left on a charger for too long when the battery is charged will fuse the battery. Yes they could have made 2 separate components to charge the toothbrush and the machine but then wouldnt be $60 but WAY more.<br />- sound: yes a bit loud but not a jackhammer as described, sheesh people are SO sensitive<br />- to avoid calcium deposits after every use i pull out the tank, rinse it and set it down on a microfiber cloth to air dry. Didnt have a leack of ONE drop<br />- to avoid some of the river flooding crazy out of your month, when doing the front part, push from behind your tongue gently on the back of the teeth, that will avoid drowning and the water is less likely to sprinkle against the mirror if you open a bit your mouth to see what you are doing in the mirror<br />- Toothbrush speaking husband says is great works just fine for him. You still have to move the head up and down left and right cause it doesnt rotate, but that is the good of it because the vibration and manual work takes care of the nastiest stains (ie coffee he drinks by the gallon)<br /><br />All i can tell is i am really in awe from this machine. The first time i used it i spit blood all over. The second time one tooth bled. Third time on nada not a drop of blood. Today on my 4th day i ATE an apple with my teeth with no bleeding at all no pain either.. I dont remember when was last time i did it, i used to cut the apple with a knife and chew it with my back teeth. The clinging pain is gone. I dont feel like the heart beating in my gums anymore. I got rid of 90% of the tartar rings already. And the stains are mostly gone (not even the dentist cleaning was able in one time to get rid of those stains in 2 teeth. This machine almost erased one and halved the color on the other).<br /><br />IF you have gums disease you MUST get this thing.<br /><br />I will update if i have mechanical issues in the next future and how it solved.<br />But seriously.. risk totally worth itNE drop<br />- to avoid some of the river flooding crazy out of your month, when doing the front part, push from behind your tongue gently on the back of the teeth, that will avoid drowning and the water is less likely to sprinkle against the mirror if you open a bit your mouth to see what you are doing in the mirror<br />- Toothbrush speaking husband says is great works just fine for him. You still have to move the head up and down left and right cause it doesnt rotate, but that is the good of it because the vibration and manual work takes care of the nastiest stains (ie coffee he drinks by the gallon)<br /><br />All i can tell is i am really in awe from this machine. The first time i used it i spit blood all over. The second time one tooth bled. Third time on nada not a drop of blood. Today on my 4th day i ATE an apple with my teeth with no bleeding at all no pain either..   948. After two months, I can say that I love the Waterpik! I was skeptical at first: would it really do a better job than a standard toothbrush and dental floss? Yes, to the toothbrush question and &#34;most of the time&#34; regarding the dental floss. I actually use the Waterpik and regular floss, as well, to make sure my teeth are super clean.<br /><br />In using the pause button, make sure to do two things: keep the dial set at 3 or below, and press the button firmly. If you have the dial set above 3, the pause button will stick. In my case, the button eventually stuck permanently, and I contacted the company who immediately sent a replacement and told me not to exceed &#34;3&#34; when using the pik. If you don't press the pause button firmly, you'll spray water all over.<br /><br />Well worth the money, I think.

  1038. The ease of working through my mouth with the Waterpik has definitely gotten me to improve my own dental health. It effectively gets bits of food out from between my teeth, although I still need to use traditional floss to get rid of the plaque that the Waterpik isn't able to get. Overall, I'd recommend this product to anyone who wants to improve their oral care habits, like I did.<br /><br />A couple notes:<br /><br />- It's louder than I expected. The motor surprised me the first time I turned it on. If you live with someone who is a light sleeper, be wary of this.<br /><br />- The toothbrush is a two-speed. The button turns the brush on at the first, slower speed setting. Pressing the button again switches the brush to the second, faster speed setting and pressing the button a third time turns the brush off. I use the first speed setting, which means, to turn the brush off, I need to switch to the second speed. If I keep the brush in my mouth to turn it off, it's a bit jarring. If I take the brush out of my mouth, the second speed setting sprays toothpaste everywhere.

I've made a few water messes so now after I'm done, I leave the waterpick in the sink to drain rather than hook it back on. Also there are three bright green LED on the toothbrush and at night they shine bright which I personally find very annoying. Lastly, on the toothbrush, after use, the water drains down the handle of the toothbrush and settles on the holder and the holder gets pretty dirty but it can be cleaned using the waterpick. Other than that it's nice. I would buy again.

They said without seeing the unit they could not determine if it was the toothbrush unit or the base unit which was malfunctioning. They said a complete new unit would be shipped and I should receive it within 10 days. A new unit was received and works well. They stood by their product and did what they said they would do.

Doesn't leave many choices for toothpastes.

  1131. This Pik requires TWO (2) hands to operate it when you first start. It seems to me that it was never given to a peer group to test out before it was put on the market, or when they assembled it they put the WATER VALVE contained in the handle backward. Once you turn the switch from 0 to 1 you have water under pressure going to the Pik and it will squirt all over unless you have the button on the water Pik handle depressed or you have the Pik in your mouth and you are holding it there between your teeth. You have to keep the button depressed to keep the water from squirting out and release the button on the water Pik handle to get the water to come out which I believe is CONTRARY, BACKWARD to how things normally work in this world. If a person has only one hand available to use it would be tricky. Once you get over the backward type of operation it will do the job it was intended for.

  1140. For the price, you just can't get a better tool for cleaner, healthier teeth. Individually, the water flosser and the sonic toothbrush are both great products. In a well-designed, single unit, the products are unbeatable. If you're on the fence, hop off now.<br /><br />I've been using both the water flosser and the sonic toothbrush for about a week, and my teeth have never felt cleaner. The water flosser, complete with adjustable pressure setting and multiple tips, is great. Waterpik makes models with more bells and whistles, but this model contains everything you need in a water flosser. I've used a Waterpik flosser before, but I forgot just how effective they are at removing debris in between teeth and gums. The results are astounding, to say the least.<br /><br />The sonic toothbrush, for me, was the big question mark. I've been a longstanding Sonicare user, so I was skeptical whether Waterpik's sonic toothbrush was as effective. The Waterpik model, especially compared with many of the Sonicare models, is pretty basic. That being said, I took me exactly one use before I was sold on the Waterpik model. The difference is the Waterpik is much more powerful than the Sonicare. That additional power makes it easier to clean and whiten teeth, and I've noticed the difference: the toothbrush works fantastic! Also, the LEDs on the toothbrush are very handy to determine how much charge is remaining on the toothbrush.<br /><br />As for the combined unit, it's very nicely put together. The convenience of having one plug for both your toothbrush and your water flosser leaves your precious bathroom outlets free for other things. The water reservoir is well sized for a complete cleaning, and is easy to fill and empty. The covered storage for both piks and brush heads is a very nice feature. And, the charging station for the sonic toothbrush is well thought out. Unlike the Sonicare that sits on top of the charging platform, the Waterpik charger has an open bottom with a ring around the base to charge so the unit is never sitting in water (the latter results in a horrible build-up of mold and debris).<br /><br />Waterpik has combined their proven water flosser with a powerful sonic toothbrush in one very well executed unit. I'd buy one again without hesitation.
  1141. Ordered this the 14th of October and it said the water pick would be here between the 17-20 but it's not. Supper excited to get it but don't know when it will show up.
  1142. I was considering professional teeth whitening before buying. Use this twice a day for just two weeks (with a good baking soda/peroxide toothpaste), and my teeth were shades whiter. It comes with a number of accessories that I haven't used yet, but it's almost time to replace the brush head. Oh, and it lasts over a week (one person\twice a day) with just one overnight charge, which is nice.<br /><br />Water flossing takes getting used to, but it's almost therapeutic after you get the hang of it - and it feels much less invasive than regular flossing. You can adjust the flow, so finding the pressure most comfortable for you is easy.
  1143. Before I bought this, I went to the dentist and he said I have to floss more.<br />Then I bought this and use it every night on Setting #7 or #8<br />As a test I did not floss while using this product.<br />Six months later went back to the dentist and he exclaimed that I must have been flossing like a pro since the last time I saw him!
  1144. Has the following design failures:<br /><br />1) The holder for the waterpik barely grips the bottom of the handle. This means that you constantly knock it off and it ends up on the counter. At the very least, you will knock it off every time you try to fill the tank by removing it. Since the water hose is stiff, it will pop off the handle a lot just when you try to put it into the holder. The other models hold it securely in the middle of the handle, apparently they wanted to save a cent or two in plastic.<br /><br />2) The waterpik handle is too high in the holder. That exacerbates 1 above.<br /><br />3) The left side of the top is a badly designed tank to hold the tooth brush heads. It is useless. You can’t easily add or take out the heads and it does not dry out very easily. Do you really want the kids grubby hands rooting around trying to do this every morning? I didn’t think so. You should have a separate holder for those heads that is external to this unit.<br /><br />4) The water tank is too small because of the brush holder.<br /><br />5) The pause button on the handle will start sticking in the down position pretty soon. It is not something you can take apart and cleanup to repair it. You will then have to use the switch to pause the unit. Why would the most used part of the system be the first to break?<br /><br />It appears the waterpik company is on a downward quality slide, they don’t have any serious competitors so they are just going to milk the customers while they can.
  1145. It works well...wish was qieuter the water pik part
  1146. This is my second Waterpic and the first one with the tooth brush in the unit. I have found it to be a great addition to dental care. Nice compact unit.
  1147. I like doing things by hand more. hand floss is better. this is good for a touch up.
  1148. Amazon Rocks!!! ;)

  1166. Great combination healthcare instrument.
  1167. Very powerful. Haven't had a toothbrush like this in a very long time, and glad to make the switch back. The toothbrush has two settings, a low and a high setting. The high is every powerful, get used to the low setting first before trying the high one. The waterpik has 10 settings, and once again, get used to the lower settings first, do not jump straight to the highest setting. This also comes with a variety of waterpik attachments, and 2 different toothbrush heads. Each with a different use. And one more thing, also a travel case for the brush! I am sure these are normally recmmended for anyone with braces (which I had previously, and this IS a must-have) however anyone wanting a little more focus on their teeth-health care should invest in this. This is also very santitary and takes little space on the counter. The cord is a decent length. I wish I had come across this sooner, this was definately one of the best purchases I made. Compare around like I did, but I am sure you will come back to this one. Not many more are going to be able to offer everything this one has and does.

  1248. My cleaning habits have been: brush once a night, thoroughly floss once or twice a week, and to attend a routine dentist visit every 6 months. This routine has been failing for a long time considering I have not gone one year in the past decade without having a cavity show up on an x-ray. And, thanks to a few fillings from a young dentist, many of my teeth are now very sensitive to flossing. Though, do not get me wrong, my teeth are not yellow and decaying - I just am not sitting at home enough to follow the recommended &#34;3 times a day&#34; routine. After two weeks, my impression is that this sonic toothbrush and water flosser pair work fairly well. I feel as though the spaces between my teeth and my gums are much cleaner after using this product. The water flosser is actually very easy and quick to use, however the first few times you might make a mess, so keep a towel handy. And, though the product feels very flimsy, it is very functional. At first I feared possible mold build up, but this product is well designed, so mold should not be an issue. Just do not leave it plugged in all the time or the wireless charger will destroy the toothbrush's battery. As an experiment for this brush, my cleaning habits will not change much. I will be using the sonic brush and water flosser once a night and the same occasional floss from before. Upon my next dental visit this review will be updated. Update (6/28/16): I skipped a dental appointment, did not floss, and stopped using the water flosser daily after 4 months. I know - such weak will power... However, I used the water flosser about once a month and brushed once a night every night without fail. The result? No cavities for the first time in 10 years!
  1249. I have spent a lot of years using a manual toothbrush, so, this has been quite the adjustment. Let's start with the tooth brush. It does an amazing job at cleaning your teeth. It comes with two brushes a mini, and a regular size brush head. I gave the regular one to my son and he says its great. The mini gets into all the crevices and behind the teeth exceptionally well. This is great since the hygienist always seems to spend more time with the back 4 molars. With this it feels like I had my teeth cleaned at the dentist. Dont get me wrong, my oral hygiene has always been very good. I have only had 2 cavities my whole life. But, I am over 40 and I have started developing sensitivities to cold and hot. My dentist said that I have been brushing to hard and that has contributed to loss of enamel. This has a soft bristle brush and removes all the plaque without the vigorous brushing. My only complaint is that the vibrations tends to tickle, not sure if they can do anything about that, Another great thing about this toothbrush is that it gives 30 sec timer that briefly pauses to let you move on to the next quadrant ensuring you get the whole two minutes of brush time.<br />As for the water pick, it too is great! I still floss, mostly out of habit, but, the floss is always clean.I never had braces growing up so I do have spaces between my teeth. Despite this, I never have anything on the floss string. As a matter of fact, lately when I eat steak or similar food I use the water pic to freshen my mouth and remove any debris. Quick, easy, complete clean after meals. Initially there will be clean up while you get used to flooding your mouth. I also put a capful of mouthwash in the water container, and I also use warm water. That sensitivity thing. Overall this is a wonderful product. You can still use your favorite toothpaste and mouthwash, and its only slightly more expensive than just a plain ole waterpic.<br />Update: definitely happy with this purchase! Last checkup went great! Plus no longer do I suffer from cold sensitivity!! By the end of my check up the hygienist had stopped using that soothing voice they use on terrified patients lol. If you on the fence buy this product, you will be happy you did!reat! Plus no longer do I suffer from cold sensitivity!! By the end of my check up the hygienist had stopped using that soothing voice they use on terrified patients lol. If you on the fence buy this product, you will be happy you did!

I have had this appliance for some time now and couldn't be more pleased. The flossing action is superior to the older models. The picks meet any cleaning need one might have and are easy to change. The tank holds enough water for a thorough flossing.l To have the Sonic toothbrush right there at hand is an extra added bonus. This Sonic bush seems to be an improvement over the last model: There are different speeds in both brushing and flossing. It has a timer on it so that I know how long I've been on each section of my mouth. I don't have to watch the clock. My teeth have never looked or felt better! 9/21/2016 UPDATE: The toothbrush is not holding a full charge anymore and there are no replacement batteries. I called Waterpik and they were so incredibly nice and helpful. A brand new full unit is on its way to me. I didn't even have to produce my Amazon.com invoice. They just needed the serial number and model number. I can't say enough good about this company or this very excellent product.

She said my pockets were significantly reduced and there was only light tartar build-up. I only needed the normal dental picks for my cleaning. One thing I would add that no one else has probably added is that the sonic toothbrush has excellent battery capacity. It may not be the best wizbang toothbrush, but if you can figure out how to make the best out of it. It is to brushing what safety razors is to shaving, gets the job done quite well..<br /><br />The ONLY problem is that it is not using international voltages. Sticking with 110V AC only means that your device cannot be used internationally. Waterpik should really consider improving that part.<br /><br />It is small, but it does take countertop space. Wall mounting model might be a good idea too. It is a bit noisy to use, but it seems to be using a reciprocating pump to generate the pressure. Body is plastic, but it is a very good quality plastic.

The design covers the obvious easy-use buttons and controls, but also has the thoughtful additions of vented storage space for the brushes and irrigator tips, and the little flat spot on the back of the toothbrush handle so that it doesn't roll off the counter to crash on the floor.   1461. Came in nice packaging; items were well protected.<br /><br />Includes a carrying case for two brush heads and the main brush itself. The main machine has the floss attached and a little brush/tip container that allows air flow to enhance drying. The two clear glass parts are detachable for washing.<br /><br />The long power cord can be crammed into the bottom of the base to hide and then run through a small cut out at the bottom so it stays in place at any customized length you want.<br /><br />The floss pressure gets pretty high actually and the pressure works pretty well. The one problem I had was that the machine itself is loud. Really loud. On the level of my phone on vibrate while sitting on a tin surface. This is only while using the floss stick. I'll probably only use it in the mornings.<br /><br />With that said, I have awful dental habits. The main issue being I'm crazy CRAZY LAZY. The best part of this set is that the toothbrush feels wonderful on my gums. It's almost like a massage and the bristles really clearing out between my teeth. The floss water does get in-between my teeth really well and it feels refreshing.   1465. This is a product that is exactly as advertised. The water flosser is great; no more floss fingers for me! Having said that, using the flosser does take some getting used to. I found that a setting of 9 was needed to really clean my teeth. This results in a sound that ran my cat out of the bathroom the first time I used it. It is definitely not something you should plan on using outside of your sleeping baby's or significant others room. There is a learning curve in positioning the flosser correctly so that the water hits the bottom and backs of all your teeth. Once you've mastered it, your teeth will feel dentist clean every time you use the flosser. My one complaint is for the Sonic Toothbrush. I found the 1st setting to be too soft and the 2nd setting to be too high, no mid-range available. I used a Braun electric toothbrush with a small round head befor the Waterpik, so getting used to the larger head on the Waterpik is difficult. Overall, however, my teeth are clean and my gums feel healthy.
  1466. We bought this after a suggestion from our dentist when we disclosed our less than perfect flossing habits (non habits). For those with bridges, braces or teeth with no gaps this is way way easier than flossing and it comes with a variety of heads to use to tackle different problems.<br /><br />A couple of things of note,<br />The pressure settings from 0-10 are nice to customize for those with sensitive teeth.<br />Tooth brush has 2 power settings<br />I have not tried it yet but it does include the use of listerine in the flosser directions<br />The size is fairly compact for the 2 items in one unless you don't have a lot of counter space<br />Can be a bit messy with water spraying
